Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: The school reports that the child was caught bullying a classmate, and the parent needs to respond
Situation2: They see a group of teenagers ignoring the no-diving signs near the pool edge.
Story: I was sitting on the bleachers at the school gym, waiting for the principal to call me in about my son. My phone buzzed with a message: “Your child was involved in a bullying incident. Please come to the office.” My heart sank. As a parent, I knew I had to be there for him, to listen, to guide, to show him right from wrong. But just as I stood up, my radio crackled. “Lifeguard, we’ve got a group of teens diving at the deep end. Please respond.” I looked out the window and saw the pool through the glass—kids laughing, splashing, ignoring the big red “NO DIVING” signs. My job as a lifeguard demanded I act immediately, enforce the rules, keep everyone safe. But my son needed me, maybe more than ever. I felt torn in two, the weight of both roles pressing down on me, each demanding my full attention, each expecting me to do the right thing. My hands shook as I tried to decide which responsibility to answer first.
